Allopseudospirillum japonicum is a species of bacteria that belongs to the Alphaproteobacteria class. It is a gram-negative, spiral-shaped, and motile bacterium. Allopseudospirillum japonicum was first isolated from soil samples collected in Japan.

This species is characterized by its ability to grow under both aerobic and microaerobic conditions. It can utilize a variety of organic compounds, such as carbohydrates and organic acids, as carbon and energy sources. Allopseudospirillum japonicum is also known to be capable of nitrogen fixation, a process that allows it to convert atmospheric nitrogen into a form that can be used by plants and other organisms.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Allopseudospirillum japonicum is closely related to other members of the Alphaproteobacteria class, particularly within the Rhodobacteraceae family. This taxonomic placement suggests that Allopseudospirillum japonicum shares common evolutionary origins and ecological roles with other bacteria found in soil and aquatic environments.
